children.subject: So would you say a solid theory base (126, 127, 189, 170, 188) + the material covered in 186 + 61B + 61C + possibly 168 (if I get off the wl)/161 would be enough to be a successful software engineer if I choose that path? I honestly didn't find 186 to be that challenging, and I feel like I'm either overestimating how useful a harder design class would be or I'm missing out on something in a CS education.

Yes, definitely. You don't need 162 to be a successful software engineer. There's not as much freedom for design in the projects as they might have you believe (the TAs kinda point you in one direction), and the majority of your time on the projects will be spent debugging C code rather than designing and implementing. I still thought it was a worthwhile experience, but I don't feel like I would have missed out if I didn't take it.

Others may give a more thorough answer, but having just taken it I'll say that I don't think 162 is critical. I also find theory classes more interesting than design classes. Theory classes are harder to learn yourself, so you should focus on those instead if you have to choose. The material in 162 isn't hard to learn on your own - you could just read about it if you wanted to. My main takeaway was the high-level design ideas of file systems, virtual addresses, caches, synchronization, etc. Having taken 186, you probably already know enough about synchronization. The other concepts are just 61C material with slightly more depth. I'd say if you enjoy 61C next semester and want to learn more, then take 162. Otherwise it's not necessary.

Does 162 prepare you for getting and performing in those roles? Also, would not having OS on my resume be a barrier of entry to getting the interview? If I do end up taking 162 it would be in spring, so anywhere I recruit for in fall won't see it on my resume (though I can explain my plan if I get to the interview stage).

I'd just want to pitch in that I've come across recruiters that'd specifically look for the Operating Systems class on your resume. This again depends on the particular SWE role and the company, but if you work on anything relating to systems (which is obviously everywhere in SWE), it is a de-facto requirement. Then again, no class is critical and you are free to use your own judgement. All I can say is 186 or 61C knowledge is definitely not sufficient for working on real-world systems, which are far more complex than you'd encounter in any class here anyway.

Sometimes, a class may not be worthwhile or enjoyable to you but the knowledge you gain would be essential in the future.

history.content:
Since you’re even questioning in the first place....Take it. What’s there to lose? 

------------------------------------------

it doesn't seem like you are sacrificing 189.. it's just one of the 2 "prereqs" to machine learning.  If you were considering pursuing higher level edu in ML, then I think it would be a matter of discussion. Since you are industry focused I personally feel there is no debate here in switching out 126 for 162.  Saying you are interested in any back-end dev and not having OS knowledge would raise some ??? for a lot of potential employers.  

(I have near 0 interest in ML stuff so I am biased)

Since you’re even questioning in the first place....Take it. What’s there to lose?

Since you are industry focused I personally feel there is no close to no debate here in switching out 126 for 162.  Saying you are interested in back-end dev and not having OS knowledge would raise some ??? for a lot of potential employers.

children.subject: @student response, I'm original anon and I agree. It's just that I have to sacrifice taking 1 important course to take it, most likely 126. Do you think taking 162 and having to self-study 126 is better than self-studying the 162 material and taking 126 (& finishing the ML core)? I'm fairly good at self-studying material, but for 126 at least the material isn't the difficult part, its keeping up with the pace and problem/exam difficulty that makes you better. But I suppose something similar can be said for 162.

Perspective of a student that has taken CS162:

It looks good on your resume and it might make you a stronger engineer. It is a design course and all, but I agree with the above response that some TAs will steer you in a direction, so there isn't really that much open ended-ness. I would actually argue CS161 (non design course) proj2 had more open ended-ness; at least this semester it did. With that said, the most gained out of CS162 was the concepts learned. So if you don't plan on formally taking it, you should at least look over the webcasts and discussion worksheets.

history.content:
I've been kind of conflicted as to whether I should take 162 or not. I have 1 more year at Cal. I am taking 61c next semester, so I would take 162 in spring. So far, I've found my theory focused classes to be more interesting than the design ones. I have an interest in the Machine Learning/AI side (like everyone else lmao), but I really haven't decided whether I want to do that or Software engineering. I don't plan on going to grad school beyond maybe a 1-2 year masters (almost certainly no PhD), so SWE roles will definitely be more plentiful and attainable. So far I've taken 186, 188, and 170 as upper division courses and done very well in all of them. To take 162 and have a balanced workload in my last 2 semesters I would have to sacrifice taking a course like 126 (and end up taking data100/168, 189, 162, 127). If I choose not to take 162, I could complete 126, 127 and 189, and take something lighter like 161 (or 168 if I make it of the WL) on the SWE side.

Is 162 worth it if I think there's a good chance I'll end up a software engineer, even though I'm more interested in the mathy/ML/theory side of CS (and I'm not interested in anything more than a masters)? What parts of it (beyond the stuff covered by 186) make it that way if it is?

The posts I've seen on eecs101 about 162 seem a bit mixed, with some saying its absolutely essential, and others saying it wasn't worth it, so if anyone has a fresh perspective, please share.
history.subject: 162 Importance
